image.altText: Army tanks in a field

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu convenesÂ Israel's expanded emergency cabinet for the first time, saying the national unity on display sends a message at home and abroad as the country gears up to "demolish Hamas" in Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: Israeli army 'waiting for political decision' on Gaza invasion as Netanyahu convenes emergency cabinet

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The White House National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan has told CBS the nation fears an escalation of the war between Israel and Hamas and the prospect of Iran getting directly involved. Mr Sullivan cited the possibility of a new battle front on the Israel-Lebanon border. "We can't rule out that Iran would choose to get directly engaged some way," he said. "We have to prepare for every possible contingency."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US fears escalation of war, says Security Advisor

children.content: The White House National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan has told CBS the nation fears an escalation of the war between Israel and Hamas and the prospect of Iran getting directly involved.
Mr Sullivan cited the possibility of a new battle front on the Israel-Lebanon border.
"We can't rule out that Iran would choose to get directly engaged some way," he said.
"We have to prepare for every possible contingency."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli Defence Minister has said Israel has no interest in waging war on its northern front, and that if the Lebanese group Hezbollah restrains itself, Israel will respect the situation along the border as it is today. Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel says it will respect situation near Lebanon

children.content: Israeli Defence Minister has said Israel has no interest in waging war on its northern front, and that if the Lebanese group Hezbollah restrains itself, Israel will respect the situation along the border as it is today.
Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We're getting more photos sent through by our digital producer Riley Stuart, who is on the ground in Israel now. These photos were taken near Gaza. Earlier tonight Riley was around 30km from the Gaza border. We're in the kibbutz of Kfar Aza, which is 2km from the Gaza fence. So far, 53 civilians are confirmed to have died here. More than 100 Hamas terrorists were found here after last Saturday's massacre. A kibbutz is a Hebrew word which basically equates to a small farming community. IDF forces are still clearing homes here, making sure there are no explosives. On one house's front verge, a live grenade remains among the debris. People's possessions remain strewn about their houses, and bullets and guns used by the Hamas militants.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bullets, guns strewn around homes near Gaza

children.content: Â
We're getting more photos sent through by our digital producer Riley Stuart, who is on the ground in Israel now.
Â
These photos were taken near Gaza.
Earlier tonight
Riley was around 30km from the Gaza border.
Â
We're in the kibbutz of Kfar Aza, which is 2km from the Gaza fence.
So far, 53 civilians are confirmed to have died here.
More than 100 Hamas terrorists were found here after last Saturday's massacre.
A kibbutz is a Hebrew word which basically equates to a small farming community.
IDF forces are still clearing homes here, making sure there are no explosives.
On one house's front verge, a live grenade remains among the debris.
People's possessions remain strewn about their houses, and bullets and guns used by the Hamas militants.

items.synopsis: Israel vows to annihilate the militant group Hamas in retaliation for a rampage by its fighters in Israeli towns.

title.children: Gaza families fear more destruction as ground assault looms

image.altText: Headshot of a smiling Indigenous man in a patterned shirt

items.synopsis: While many say they are devastated by the No result in Saturday's referendum, First Nations leaders around the country are also hopeful that positive change can result.

image.altText: Albanese and Burney stand behind podiums in front of the Australian, Indigenous and Torres Strait flags

image.altText: A map of Australia against a background of orange and purple stripes.

items.synopsis: Australia has voted No in the referendum, butÂ the vote hasn't been uniform across states and cities. A small number of electorates, mainly inÂ inner cities, are projected to have voted Yes.

title.children: A clear pattern has emerged in the way cities have voted in this referendum

image.altText: a surfer with his surfboard on the floor votes at a polling centre in  bondi for the indigenous voice to parliament referendum

items.synopsis: Support for Yes was strongest in the inner suburbs, while the majority of outer suburban, regional and rural voters said No. But analysts say the reasons why voters rejected the referendum question is more complex.

image.altText: David Littleproud stands over the hills in Maranoa.

title.children: 'Intellectual arrogance': The Queensland electorate that returned the country's strongest no vote

items.synopsis: The Israel Defense Forces' top spokesman says the killing of senior Hamas members is a "top priority". But analysts say tracking down these leaders will be complicated, and even if Israel is able to "eliminate" itsÂ targets, there is no guarantee it will bring an end to this war.

items.synopsis: Most people gainÂ small amounts of weightÂ each year as they age. But can coffee help prevent this gradual weight gain?

title.children: Can coffee help you avoid putting on weight as you age?

image.altText: Paul Fuller's business's bank accounts were drained of $1.2 million by hackers.

items.synopsis: A hacker who stole $1.2 million from a family business already hadÂ confidential information before the theft occurred. Those in the field say cybercrime is rapidly evolving, and small businesses are facing increasing and targeted threats.

title.children: Paul's family business lost $1.2 million to a hacker. It's a sign cyber crime is evolving

image.altText: A young person expressing emotion.

items.synopsis: On a drizzly morning in March, thousands lined the streets of Adelaide to witness SA legislate a state-based First Nations Voice to Parliament.Â Seven months later, the outcome at a national level could scarcely have been more different.

title.children: What went wrong for the Yes campaign in South Australia?

image.altText: young woman with nose piercings holding a baby wearing a white top.

items.synopsis: Unlike the other 20 or so cooing and crying babies attending a ceremony in Kalgoorlie, SeanÂ is soundÂ asleep âÂ blissfully unaware he's being welcomed intoÂ a world that was not quite expecting him.

title.children: Sean's 21-year-old mum did not know she was expecting him until she went into labour

items.synopsis: When Europeans colonised Tasmania they developed a hysterical fear of snakes but unwittingly provided them with the perfect food source,Â rabbits, which led to one venomous species growing into near 2-metre giants.

image.altText: Two women, one blonde and one with red curly hair.

items.synopsis: In a digitally connected world, one in three Australians still report feeling lonely. From dinner parties with strangers to pledging to have a blind "friendship date" every week for a year, these women are finding creative solutions when it comes to making new friends as an adult.Â

title.children: Friendship blind dates and dinner with strangers: How to make friends as an adult

image.altText: Jimmy Thomson surrounded by flowers and foliage in his garden.

items.synopsis: When Jimmy Thomson's wife Roslyn died last year, he was distraught. Her love of native flowers was something he couldn't shake, so he continued her weekly tradition of making and donating native floral bouquets.

title.children: Together the Thomsons were a team. Now Jimmy is keeping his and his wife's floral bouquet tradition alive

image.altText: the skull of a deer with large antlers hangs on a shed wall
